Anatoli,

Thanks for the suggestion I am going to read through that Premix

manual I am sure that it will be a great help. It will certaintly help
me i=
mprove my understanding of the entire simulation process thanks
for the sug=
gestion.

Chris Kelly
--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "avmokhov" <avmokhov@=
...> wrote:
>
> Hi Chris,
> As a first step I would like to recommend you t=
o read a manual for 
> the Premix program from the Chemkin suite where a ve=
ry good 
> explanation of the differences between the burner-stabilized and=
 free 
> flame and the solution method are given. Cantera is using exactly =
the 
> same algorithm to solve the 1D flame problem. What is different in 
=
> comparison with Premix, Cantera considers 1D flame as a limiting case 
> =
of axisymmetric flame. Unfortunately, I don't use both Python and 
> Matlab=
, therefore, I cannot answer all your questions. In particular,
> 1.	Tfix i=
s a fixed temperature necessary to remove translational 
> symmetry from th=
e governing equations. For free flames, if T(x) is 
> solution, T(x+x0) is =
also solution with arbitrary x0. By putting 
> temperature in some point eq=
ual to some fixed temperature we fix the 
> flame position. Usually you can=
 put Tfix equal to 800 K.
> 2.	Z1 is a relative position (from 0 to 1, usua=
lly 0.7). Zero 
> approximation for all variables is linear changed on [0,Z=
1] from 
> inlet to equilibrium values. You should play with this value to =
reach 
> faster convergence of solution. Clearly, if you make Z1 smaller, y=
ou 
> expect high burning velocities (flame thickness is small).
> 
> Hope =
that this helps, 
> Best regards, Anatoli
> 
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroup=
s.com, "transfertoschool" <ademator@> 
> wrote:
> >
> > I have been looking=
 to create a Matlab model of a freely propagating
> > flame. The python exa=
mple free_h2_air.py uses FreeFlame.py. I have
> > started out by first comp=
aring the provided demos Flame1.m and
> > flame1.py in an attempt to unders=
tand the differences between the
> > simulations in Matlab and Python. I ha=
ve also been looking through 
> the
> > tutorial files provided with Canter=
a for both Matlab and Python.
> > 
> > I believe that the following stateme=
nt in the python file flame1.py
> > 
> > f =3D BurnerFlame(gas =3D gas, gri=
d =3D inital_grid)
> > 
> > is equivalent to the series of statements found=
 throughout the 
> Matlab
> > file Flame1.m
> > 
> > 1)  f =3D Axisymmetric=
Flow(gas, 'flow');
> > 2)  set(f, 'P', p, 'grid', inital_grid);
> > 3)  bur=
ner =3D Inlet(`burner');
> > 4)  s =3D Outlet(`out');
> > 5)  f1 =3D flame(=
gas, burner, f, s);
> > 6)  setMaxJacAge(f1, max_jacobian_age(1), max_jacob=
ian_age(2));
> > 
> > From there I went and compared the Pyhton files Burne=
rFlame.py to
> > FreeFlame.py in order to see what is unique about the Free=
Flame
> > simulation and I concluded the following.
> > 
> > FreeFlame.py i=
ntroduces a few extra statements when compared to
> > BurnerFlame.py See th=
e list below.
> > 
> > 7) from Cantera import _cantera
> > 8) self.tfix =3D=
 tfix
> > 9) self.setFixedTemperature(self.tfix)
> > 10) def setFixedTemper=
ature(self, temp)
> > 11) _cantera.sim1D_setFixedTemperature(self._hndl, te=
mp)
> > 
> > FreeFlame.py also modifies the following statements from 
> Bu=
rnerFlame.py
> > 
> > 12) def _init_(self, gas =3D None, grid =3D None, tfi=
x =3D 500.0): 
> > in this statement burner =3D None and outlet =3D None is=
 removed while
> > tfix is added
> > 13) self.flame =3D AxisymmetricFlow(`f=
lame', gas =3D gas, type=3D2)
> > the difference with this statement was th=
at type=3D2 was added
> > 14) z1 =3D 0.5 is changed from 0.2
> > 15) locs =
=3D array([0.0, 0.3, z1, 1.0], `d') the entry 0.3 is added to
> > the array=

> > 16) self.setProfile(`u', locs, [u0, u0, u1, u1]) a second u0 is 
> add=
ed
> > 17) self.setProfile(`T', locs, [t0, t0, teq, teq]) a second u0 is 
>=
 added
> > 18) self.setProfile(gas.speciesName(n), locs, [yin[n], yin[n], y=
eq
> [n],
> > yeq[n]) a second yin[n] is added.
> > 
> > From this point I =
was looking to build the model of free_h2_air.py 
> in
> > Matlab. I order =
to do this it looks as if I will need to
> > 
> > - use the Matlab code in =
points 1 to 6 and modify it to add in the
> > effects of the points 7 to 18=
 which was used in the python code.
> > 
> > A few questions
> > 
> > - How=
 do you implement the tfix variable?
> > - What does type=3D2 mean for Axis=
ymmetricFlow?
> > - Why is Z1 changed to .5?
> > - Why is locs array modifi=
ed to have 4 entries which in turn
> > introduces a second u0, t0 and yin[n=
] (points 15 to 18 above)?
> > 
> > Does anyone have any suggestions to hel=
p me understand how to do 
> this
> > or can help explain this to me?
> > 
=
> > Thank you in advance.
> > 
> > Chris Kelly
> > 
> > 
> > --- In cantera=
@yahoogroups.com, "transfertoschool" <ademator@> 
> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi a=
ll,
> > > 
> > > I was experimenting with the example free_h2_air.py and I =
have 
> been
> > > able to run the example using python. However, I would p=
refer to 
> do my
> > > work in Matlab if possible. I was wondering if ther=
e was a Matlab
> > > function that can be used in place of the FreeFlame fu=
nction used 
> in
> > > the python example? I am new to cantera and was loo=
king to run
> > > different simulations with this example via matlab if pos=
sible.
> > > 
> > > Thank you
> > > 
> > > Chris Kelly
